subject: Investing
title: Home Bias: Why We Over-Invest Locally
description: Learn Home Bias: Why We Over-Invest Locally in one minute.

hook.text: Japanese investors in 1989 had 98% in domestic stocks. The Nikkei then fell 80% and didn't recover for 34 years.

buildup.text: Home bias is the tendency to over-allocate to your own country's stocks due to familiarity and comfort.

discovery.text: It feels safer to invest in companies you know, but concentration in one economy magnifies country-specific risk.

twist.text: Many global companies earn revenue worldwide. Apple gets 60% of revenue outside the US, offering built-in global exposure.

climax.text: Match your allocation roughly to global market cap weights, then adjust for your income currency and risk tolerance.

punchline.text: Familiarity is comforting but costly. Diversify beyond your borders.

quiz.question: What is home bias in investing?
options: Over-allocating to your own country's stocks
